1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Hemophilus influenzae type B infection - Meningococcal infectious disease, Neisseria meningitidis serogroups C and Y; Prophylaxis: (aged 2 to 18 months) 4-dose series, 0.5 mL IM at 2, 4, 6, and 12 to 15 months of age; may be administered as early as 6 weeks of age; the fourth dose may be given at up to 18 months of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Hemophilus influenzae type B infection - Meningococcal infectious disease, Neisseria meningitidis serogroups C and Y; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe allergic reactions (eg, anaphylaxis) to any Meningococcal-, Haemophilus influenzae type b-, or tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine or any component of product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Guillain-Barr syndrome within 6 weeks of prior tetanus toxoid vaccination; consider risks and benefits
  • hypersensitivity, including anaphylaxis, may occur; have appropriate supportive medical treatment readily available
  • immunosuppressed children, including those receiving immunosuppressive therapy; immune response to vaccine may be suboptimal
  • not a substitute for routine tetanus immunization
  • premature infants; apnea has been reported following IM vaccination
  • syncope, with transient neurological signs (eg, visual disturbance, paresthesia, tonic-clonic limb movements), may occur; put procedures in place to avoid falling injury and to restore cerebral perfusion
  • report suspected adverse reactions to VAERS at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono:
• Haemophilus B Vaccine: C (FDA)
  • Haemophilus B Vaccine: B2 (AUS)
  • Meningococcal Vaccine, Tetanus Toxoid Conjugate Bivalent: Unknown

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Haemophilus B Vaccine: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Meningococcal Vaccine, Tetanus Toxoid Conjugate Bivalent: Unknown

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (any, 20.6% to 35.5%; greater than 30 mm, 0.1% to 0.7%), Injection site pain (United States subset: all grade, 41.4% to 46.2%; grade 3, 1.6% to 3.7%), Swelling at injection site (any, 14.7% to 25.4%; greater than 30 mm, 0.3% to 0.6%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Loss of appetite (all grade, 30.1% to 33.8%; grade 3, 0.5% to 1.1%)
  • Neurologic:Somnolence (all grade, 48.7% to 62.8%; grade 3, 1.7% to 3.2%)
  • Psychiatric:Irritability (all grade, 62.1% to 70.8%; grade 3, 2.5% to 4.8%)
  • Other:Fever (United States subset: 100.4 degrees F or higher, 11% to 25.9%; 102.2 degrees F or higher, 1.1% to 3.2%; higher than 104 degrees F, up to 0.3%)
Serious
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Respiratory:Apnea of prematurity

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The meningococcal polysaccharide/haemophilus B conjugate vaccine contains Neisseria meningitidis serogroup C and Y capsular polysaccharide antigens and Haemophilus B capsular polysaccharide (polyribosyl-ribitol-phosphate (PRP)). Administration of the vaccine triggers production of antibodies specific to the capsular polysaccharides of Neisseria meningitidis serogroups C and Y, and antibodies to PRP. The presence of anti-capsular meningococcal and anti-PRP antibodies are associated with protection from invasive meningococcal disease and invasive disease due to Haemophilus influenza type B, respectively.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intramuscular
  • Reconstitute with 0.6 mL of accompanying saline diluent only
  • Shake well
  • Administer by IM injections immediately following reconstitution
  • Administer IM injection in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh for children less than 1 year of age; deltoid muscle is usually large enough for an IM injection in older pediatric patients

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: antibody titers may be indicative of efficacy

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Menhibrix
Intramuscular Powder for Solution: (Haemophilus B Conjugate Vaccine - Meningococcal Vaccine, Tetanus Toxoid Conjugate Bivalent) 2.5 MCG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause syncope (fainting), which can be accompanied by visual disturbance, paresthesia, and tonic-clonic limb movements. Instruct caregiver to report occurrence and/or signs/symptoms.
  • This drug may cause irritability, drowsiness, loss of appetite, or fever, as well as injection-site pain, redness, or swelling.
  • Instruct caregiver to immediately report signs/symptoms of an allergic reaction to their healthcare provider.
  • Inform caregiver of the importance of the child receiving the entire series of vaccinations. If a dose is missed, another appointment should be scheduled as soon as possible.
